turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Hi, I'm having trouble with my new smart thermostat. It's not connecting to my Wi-Fi, and the temperature reading seems off. I've tried restarting it multiple times, but it's still not working. This is frustrating!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: I understand your frustration. Let's troubleshoot this. First, can you please tell me the model number of your smart thermostat? Also, confirm that your Wi-Fi network is broadcasting on a 2.4 GHz band, as that's what the thermostat requires.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Okay, the model number is T5000. And yes, I'm pretty sure the Wi-Fi is 2.4 GHz. But wait, how can I *actually* confirm that without a bunch of technical jargon? I don't want to mess anything up!

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: That's a good question. The easiest way to verify your Wi-Fi band is to log into your router's settings page. You can usually access this by typing your router's IP address (often 192.168.1.1 or 192.168.0.1) into a web browser. You'll need your router's username and password to login. From there, look for a section related to wireless settings or Wi-Fi settings. It should indicate which band your network is using. If you can't do that, let me know and we can look at other options.

turns.speaker: user
turns.utterance: Alright, I managed to get into my router settings. It *is* on the 2.4 GHz band. I still can't connect the thermostat. Is there a way to manually enter the Wi-Fi information, because it keeps saying it can't find my network?

turns.speaker: agent
turns.utterance: Yes, for the T5000 model, you should be able to manually enter the Wi-Fi credentials. On the thermostat itself, go to the network settings, and choose 'Add Network Manually'. Then, carefully type in your network name (SSID) and password. Double-check everything for typos! If that still doesn't work, there might be a problem with the thermostat itself or the signal strength. Please try one more time and report back.
